questiontext.text:
Please fill in the blanks
Most experts agree that{1:MULTICHOICE:=narrow AI#OK~general purpose AI#Wrong~decades#Wrong} has made significant progress but that we are still in {1:MULTICHOICE:=decades#OK~narrow AI#Wrong~general purpose AI#Wrong} away from a in {1:MULTICHOICE:=decades#Wrong~narrow AI#Wrong~general purpose AI#OK} solving totally different kind of problems like a human.
Unmanned weapon technology is not as novel as one might think at first glance. In fact, it can be traced back at least as far as… (only one answer)

answer.text: …the Peloponnesian War
…World War I
…World War II
…the Vietnam War

questiontext.text: What was not a contributing factor to the advent of “drone warfare”? (multiple answers)

answer.text: Casualty aversion in Western societies
Remote control via satellite
The global war on terror
Significant advances in artificial intelligence

questiontext.text: What are the challenges and risks of remotely piloting drones? (multiple answers)

answer.text: The time lag between controller input and system reaction
The high speeds at which current propeller-driven drones fly
The possible hijacking of the remote control uplink
The lacking payload capabilities of current drones

questiontext.text: How does this learning unit differentiate between military drones and robots? (only one answer)

answer.text: Drones are armed, robots are unarmed
Drones are aerial vehicles, robots move on the ground
Drones are remotely piloted, robots operate autonomously without human input
Drones are prohibited under Art. 36 of the Additional Protocol to the Geneva Conventions, robots are not

questiontext.text: What defines an autonomous weapons system according to the US’s Directive 3000.09? (only one answer)

answer.text: “[O]nce activated, [it] can engage targets with the assistance of a human operator”
“[O]nce activated, [it] can seek but not engage targets without further intervention by a human operator”
“[O]nce activated, [it] can select and engage targets without further intervention by a human operator”
“[O]nce activated, [it] can select and engage targets after intervention by a human operator”

questiontext.text: According to the nomenclature developed in this learning unit, differentiating between “automatic” and “autonomous” is a helpful figure of thought. Why? (only one answer)

answer.text: To differentiate between legal and illegal weapon systems.

To differentiate between already existing, immobile weapon systems used to defend against incoming munitions in tightly structured and controlled environments and weapon systems that operate without human control or supervision in dynamic, unstructured, open environments over an extended period of time after activation.
To differentiate between modern and outdated weapon systems.

To differentiate between defensive weapon systems operating without human control in dynamic, unstructured, open environments and offensive weapon systems used only in very tightly controlled scenarios.

questiontext.text: In autonomous weapon systems, with regard to decision-making human operator are… (only one answer)

answer.text: “in the loop”
“on the loop”
“out of the loop”
“next to the loop”

questiontext.text: Why is autonomy a trend in unmanned weapon systems? (multiple answers)

answer.text: Because autonomy renders a constant communication and remote control uplink unnecessary
Because autonomous systems are less prone to software bugs
Because some experts hope that autonomous systems might render war more humane
Because it has been argued that autonomous systems might help cut military spending

questiontext.text: Why is autonomy in weapon systems being criticized? (multiple answers)

answer.text: Because it has been argued that autonomous weapon systems might lower the threshold to war
Because some experts argue that autonomous weapon systems are unethical
Because it has been argued that autonomous weapon systems will be incapable of complying with international humanitarian law
Because some experts argue that autonomous weapon systems will put human soldiers out of work

questiontext.text: Where is the international arms control debate at the United Nations currently most active with regard to autonomous weapon systems? (only one answer)

answer.text: Security Council
General Assembly
Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons
Human Rights Council

questiontext.text: What is US public opinion regarding autonomous weapon systems according to a 2013 poll conducted by University of Massachusetts-Amherst Prof. Charli Carpenter? (only one answer)

answer.text: 75% of Americans are in favor of autonomous weapon systems
15% of Americans are against autonomous weapon systems
55% of Americans are against autonomous weapon systems
25% of Americans are in favor of autonomous weapon systems

questiontext.text: Which of these NGOs are active members of the international “Campaign to Stop Killer Robots”? (multiple answers)

answer.text: International Committee for Robot Arms Control (ICRAC)
Human Rights Watch (HRW)
World Wildlife Fund (WWF)
Article 36

questiontext.text: Which type of weapon was banned preventively under Protocol IV of the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapon? (only one answer)

answer.text: Blinding Phaser Weapons
Blinding Laser Weapons
Deafening Sound Weapons
Lethal Foam Weapons

questiontext.text: What are the currently hotly debated topics of the international arms control debate at the United Nations’ Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons with regard to autonomous weapon systems? (multiple answers)

answer.text: The impact of the robotics revolution on labor forces
The meaning of “meaningful human control” over weapon systems
The impact of artificial intelligence on privacy
The definition of “autonomy” in weapons systems

questiontext.text: As of spring 2016, with regard to autonomous weapon systems the United Nations’ Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons debate has seen… (only one answer)

answer.text: …two states parties clearly endorsing autonomous weapon systems, 14 expressing concerns, and none calling for a ban
…no states party clearly endorsing autonomous weapon systems, many expressing concerns, and 14 calling for a ban
…many states party clearly endorsing autonomous weapon systems, none expressing concerns, and none calling for a ban
…14 states parties clearly endorsing autonomous weapon systems, many expressing concerns, and none calling for a ban

questiontext.text: “Non-“ or “less-than-lethal” weapons are designed to incapacitate targets rather than killing them by making a specific use of … (multiple answers)

answer.text: Kinetic effects
Acoustic energy
Directed energy
Extrasensory Perception

questiontext.text: Using chemical “non-“ or “less-than-lethal” riot control agents as a method of warfare is…  (only one answer)

answer.text: allowed under the Chemical Weapons Convention
prohibited under the Biological Weapons Convention
allowed under the Chemical Weapons Convention if no permanent harm is caused
prohibited under the Chemical Weapons Convention

questiontext.text: Over the last two decades, military interest in non-lethal weapon technologies has grown. Why? (multiple answers)

answer.text: Due to an increase of military operations other than war
Due to an increase of humanitarian concerns amongst members of the armed forces
Due to an increasing difficulty of distinguishing combatants from non-combatants
Due to the rising costs of lethal weapon technologies

questiontext.text: Empirical data from “non-“ or “less-than-lethal” weapon use in law enforcements suggest that…  (only one answer)

answer.text: … the number of arrests is going down
... the threshold to using force is lowered
... the threshold to using force is raised
… the number of arrests is going up

questiontext.text: Which of the following milestones in AI development is made up?

answer.text: 2005 – DARPA Grand Challenge
2008 – IBM’s SokRaTes passing Turing test
2016 – AlphaGo beating GO Grandmaster Lee Sedol
2020 – DARPA’s human vs. AI dogfight

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is true?

answer.text: Arms control is hard to implement to Artificial Intelligence as AI is not a specific weapon system but an enabler like the combustion engine.
Arms control is hard to implement to Artificial Intelligence as AI is dual use by its very nature.
Arms control is hard to implement to Artificial Intelligence as AI is software code which is, by its very nature, hard to control.

questiontext.text: In contrast to a so-called "expert system", AI based on machine learning is …

answer.text: … deterministic.
… based on a preset of variables.
… statistical analysis.
… large datasets.

questiontext.text: The relationship between arms control inspectors and AI could look like this in the future:

answer.text: Due to the technical problems with AI, major agencies like the IAEA will not use AI but humans only.
As soon as the level of "trustworthy AI" has been reached, humans will be replaced by objective AI.
AI should assist inspectors for the foreseeable future but should not be given priority.

questiontext.text: Nanotechnology refers to systems between

answer.text: 0,1nm  and 100nm
0,001nm and 1nm
1nm and 1cm

questiontext.text: Military nanotechnology...

answer.text: ...has been banned by the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons in Geneva in 2016
...is regulated in the US under the National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) of 2000
...has not been regulated yet but is the perfect candidate for preventive arms control
...has only civilian applications. Therefore there is no need for arms control

questiontext.text: Additive manufacturing, also called 3D printing, poses some risks to conventional arms control, because... (multiple answers)

answer.text: It might help to circumvent export restrictions and embargos
It might offer relatively cheap ways to procure restricted weapons
In the future it might even be possible to 3D print a nuclear weapon

questiontext.text: From an ethical perspective, human enhancement in the military field might cause problems. Why? (multiple answers)

answer.text: Wrong! It does not cause problems as it has always been present in warfare (e.g. body armor)
Every medical procedure entails certain risks for those who undergo it and the state should not have the right to order soldiers to take that risk
It might violate international law as an enhanced prisoner might not be seen as a POW but a weapon
It might prevent the prosecution of war crimes if they were committed while soldiers were enhance by drugs or stimulants

questiontext.text: One common problem to restrict emerging technologies with means of arms control is...

answer.text: ...that more and more functions are based on software rather than hardware and verification is significantly harder here
...that civilian firms aggressively push their technology into the military
...that agreed definitions of what to regulate are very hard to come up with
...that only a few states can afford these technologies and other states do not care
